to move from your own country, or to cause someone to move from their own country: The new leaders expatriated the ruling family. We lived in a residential compound designed for expatriated Dutch workers and their families.expatriate to He expatriated to St. Kitts, a tranquil Caribbean island country.
to send money out of a country to another country: The government is offering a haven for businessmen from overseas who need to expatriate their money.
More examplesFewer examplesDisillusioned by the United States, Wright had expatriated to Paris with his wife and daughter.He was born in Trinidad, educated at Oxford and then expatriated to England.A major component of the Irish gross domestic product was multinationals' profits, which were largely expatriated to other countries.The host country may decree that no fund may be expatriated until the decree is lifted.
